text: Wow zoo-oo dia so I'm gonna be talking
about managing applications on

goal here I think in kubernetes is to
make it easier to build deploy operate
upgrade decommission applications over
time and to ideally do this with minimum
toil removing the grudge rework of
getting this getting your application in
production now there's some good news
and some bad news the good news is that
we're making it easier and easier to get
apps into production the bad news is
that there's going to be more and more
apps that we need to manage in
production and this is kind of an
economic effect that is was observed
during the Industrial Revolution the
price of coal went down and then people
started to use more coal and this is
holds true and pretty much any economy
if you lower the prices people will
people will use more of it if you make
it easier they'll use more of it and I
think the fact that my voice is echoing
in this room of all of you indicates
that there is a lot of demand for making
deploying apps easier so we're gonna end
up with more apps but if you have a lot
of apps there's a lot of things that you
need to be accountable for what versions
of those apps exist where they deployed
are they healthy or not who actually
owned me out who put this on the cluster
there's just a lot of questions that you
need to answer over time and pre
kubernetes apps made it into production
by being bunch of binaries from scripts
and then boom production and in reality
it look more like this which is a bunch
of binaries some scripts and then what
exactly exists in production our current
state is that we have a bunch of

still it's really just a bunch of

these questions of where the dashboards
for this thing who owns it where the
docks
who has the SMAS and it's usually on a

internally or just tribal and all
where you like how can somebody tell me
where the health monitoring is for this

a lot of us in the kubernetes would like
ecosystem would like to see is a state
where we start to define containers Plus
manifests are a distinct version of the
application and then those versions ends
up in a catalog where you say this is
the app it's some internal name and the
app has a number of versions and then
you're able to say these instances of
that app tied to those versions and so
it's a lot less confusing when you can
go back and say all these containers map
to this version of this app which was
was built in this way and then you can
start to do things like oh I need to
have a temporary penetration test
environment or a temporary debug
environment and then what we'd like to
do is tie all those things together with
all the metadata that makes an app an
app and not just a bunch of containers
so a quick demo here this is a tectonic
